awd_titl_txt: SCH: INT: Individualizing Care in Pregnancy and Childbirth through Digital Phenotyping
awd_abstract_narration:
Bringing together researchers and physicians from the Department of Women's Health, the Texas Advanced Computing Center, and the Institute for Computational Engineering & Sciences at The University of Texas at Austin, the goal of this project is to develop a digital phenotype of pregnancy to better understand factors influencing pregnancy outcomes. Women's health represents one of the most pressing health-policy issues impacting our nation. In no medical specialty are the deficiencies of medical evidence more pronounced than in women's health, especially in obstetrics. Over the course of the human life span, birth is one of the most dangerous health episodes for both mother and baby. Worldwide, between 2.6 and 4 million pregnancies result in stillbirth annually. Unlike other leading causes of mortality, birth-related deaths are largely preventable. Today, however, most adverse pregnancy outcomes are not predictable, and cannot be prevented. In this project, the research team will passively monitor a cohort of one thousand pregnant women from their first prenatal visit to six weeks post-partum. To accomplish this, participants will download the HealthyPregnancy smartphone app developed in this project to collect in situ social and behavioral data. The application passively captures participant's interactions with people and places via sensors and software throughout pregnancy. Analysis of this large collection of digital data, in combination with traditional medical monitoring data collected via participant's medical records will result in a digital phenotype of pregnancy. The digital phenotype allows for a more complete understanding of pregnancy at the macro scale and for more detailed understanding of outcomes as a continuum rather than isolated discrete events. 

It is widely understood that activity, social support, sleep, and cognitive function are important markers of health, particularly during pregnancy. Maternal obesity is associated with a number of complications in pregnancy including gestational diabetes, pre-eclampsia, macrosomia, caesarean delivery and stillbirth. Lack of social support and social interaction is also an important risk factor and has been shown to have adverse effects on pregnancy outcomes. Sleep disturbances are associated with poor health outcomes, particularly cardiovascular disease and inflammatory responses. Additionally, short sleep duration is associated with an increased incidence in diabetes and obesity and has been associated with an increase in mortality. Research suggests that women who experience pre-eclampsia more frequently report daily cognitive failures and increased emotional dysfunction years later. With the ubiquitous use of smartphones, it is now possible to collect lived experiences or data reflecting markers of pregnancy in the wild. Collecting accelerometer and GPS over time provide an indication of physical mobility and gross motor activity. Call and text message logs detail communication events and contribute to a view of social interaction and social contacts. Additionally, power state, screen time and touch events can be used to understand potential sleep disruption. Of greater significance is the analysis of this data in aggregate over the course of pregnancy. This longitudinal view and analysis of pregnancy in the wild using machine learning and mathematical models provides both an individual's digital phenotype of pregnancy and an aggregate digital phenotype of pregnancy. By gathering and analyzing these two products, they can be used to better understand outcomes and the continuum of events leading up to pregnancy outcomes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
The United States (U.S.) is experiencing a health crisis resulting from decades of increasing health care expenses associated with ever smaller improvements in health outcomes. The development of an efficient, modern health-care system has become an increasingly critical concern. Today, the U.S. spends five times more per capita on health care than countries with similar life expectancies and while expenditures have been steadily rising, health outcomes have not improved. 

In no medical specialty are the deficiencies of medical evidence more pronounced than in obstetric care. Over the course of the human life span, birth is one of the most dangerous health episodes for both mother and baby. Although birth-related deaths are largely preventable, most adverse pregnancy outcomes are not predictable and cannot be prevented. This is because even among women with risk factors for specific complications, the majority will have uncomplicated pregnancies. However, most of the complications in pregnancy will occur in women that are considered low-risk and healthy. 

In this research, we examined a multi-pronged approach to develop and implement computational, individualized medical decision-making tools to address medical evidence gaps in pregnancy through a comprehensive data-science strategy. In an effort to develop a digital phenotype of pregnancy, we passively monitored patients through our HealthyPregnancy smartphone app, collecting data from their first prenatal visit through six weeks postpartum and combining that data with patient electronic health records noting birth outcomes, risk factors and comorbidities. 

Our first outcome was the HealthyPregnancy app, a modified version of the Beiwe app developed out of the Onela lab at Harvard University.  This app was deployed on patient's smartphones to passively collect data throughout the term of their pregnancy. A modernized version of the HealthyPregnancy app will be used to conduct a post award completion Phase I multi-center trial throughout the state of Texas to begin testing efficacy of use as a supplement to current standard of care. 

Our second outcome was the design and implementation of a cohort study from the local Austin area to collect passive monitoring data during pregnancy. The cohort study was initially designed to recruit women that would deliver through the Seton hospital system in the Austin and surrounding area, who were in their first or second trimester, and who consented to passive monitoring throughout their pregnancy to 6 weeks post-partum. Our initial study design required women to enter the study in their first trimester to simplify data analysis, but this was shown to eliminate significant portions of the maternal population. In response, we amended our IRB to include pregnant patients entering the study within the first 20 weeks. This modification required additional analysis to account for the heterogeneous time scales, but it enabled a greater pool of potential study participants, particularly those that received prenatal care from CommunityCare (CUC) clinics, and Federally Qualified Health Centers (FQHC) that care for those without health insurance. Throughout the course of this study,  we collected complete data from 95 participants.  

Our third outcome resulted in research and  investigation of existing methods and development of new methods for analyzing passive monitoring data integrated with clinical/hospitalization electronic health records. The infrastructure for data collection and monitoring/analysis of the collection pipeline to ensure that we collected high quality data while maintaining patient privacy was completed to ensure and monitor collection integrity. Study participants used their smartphone devices that had either the  IOS (N=81) or Android (N=14) operating system. Approximately 1TB of aggregated data  was collected for the study participants. Thirteen sensors were considered in the study to capture relative movement, activity, and social connection. Electronic health records requested included pregnancy outcomes and co-morbidities. Demographic data was collected for each of the study participants during study consent. Significant preprocessing was conducted to account for irregular timescales, both inter-sensor measurements and intra-sensor measurements. Initially, analysis was conducted to ensure the efficacy of using a particular sensor to ensure that both sufficient data was collected and to ensure that any outliers that existed within the data were not due to noise artifacts. 

The final outcome was the creation of a digital phenotype of pregnancy from cohort data. We used topological methods for detecting features in irregular time-series data. Results suggest that signals in the colleciive sensor data do indeed provide key insignts into relative health and wellbeing and should be considered as valuable additional information in a patient's overall health. While we did have study participants enrolled that miscarried early on, we did not have participants with rare maternal events, which prevented us from producing a full fidelity digital phenotype of pregnancy. However, our results indicate the need for a larger multi-center trial. Given our experiences with consenting patients and issues with trust and privacy, we believe it necessary to have physician participation at multiple sites that work directly as part of this future trial.


Last Modified: 02/24/2025
Modified by: Kelly P Gaither
